para: Active Areas provide a mechanism for restricting the scope of &oof2; operations to a portion of a µ. The Active Area is defined in terms of a set of pixels, called the active pixels. Pixel operations will be restricted to active pixels. Operations on &skel; &nodes; will be restricted to &nodes; with positions inside active pixels. Active &skel; &elems; are defined as &elems; with at least one active &node;, and active &skel; &sgmts; are those with an active &node; at either end. Thus active &elems; and &nodes; can extend outside the Active Area.

This menu contains commands for manipulating Active Areas. &oof2; maintains a list of previously used Active Areas, so it's possible to go back and reuse old areas. It's also possible to assign names to Active Areas to make it easier to store and recall them.

caution.para:
Not all &oof2; operations respect the Active Area. Most &skel; and µ operations do (such as element refinement or pixel selection), but most ℑ and &mesh; operations do not.
ℑ modifications do not use the Active Area because they are mostly implemented by external libraries which don't know about &oof2; internal structures.
In particular, none of the Undo or Redo commands pay any attention to Active Areas -- they can change µs; or &skels; in inactive regions.

para: Like pixel selections, Active Areas all belong to a particular µ. Activating pixels in one µ has no effect on pixels in another µ. It's possible to Copy an Active Area from one µ to another, though.

shows how the Active Area is used for pixels, &elems;, &nodes;, and &sgmts;. When an Active Area is being used, the inactive pixels are dimmed in ℑ and µ displays. (Inactive &skel; components are not dimmed, unfortunately.) The amount of dimming can be adjusted by editing the for the Active Area in the &layereditor;.
